title: Build. Tokenize. Earn: The New Way to Own and Profit - Michael Healy, —Åo-founder of Unit

rawLines.text: Good afternoon. Welcome back to the
proof of talk live stream. My name is
Gareth Jenson. I'm the managing uh I'm
the head of multimedia. I used to be the
managing editor at Cointelegraph. We've
been live streaming all day. So, as you
can hear, my brain is fried, but I'm
very excited to have this conversation.
Um, if you are joining us uh on the X uh
live stream or the YouTube live stream,
please do go ahead and drop your
comments or questions. We are talking to
Michael Healey who is the co-founder of
Unit Network. Um, before we get into any
of that, Michael, give me the TLDDR of
your history because, uh, you told me
some very interesting stuff off air.
You're involved in Wikileaks all the way
back in the day. Give us the summary in
30 seconds to 1 minute. Most definitely.
So, I'm half Singaporean, half British.
Um, been building applications since the
mid200s. So, web 2 effectively when the
internet post.com bubble became a bit
more dynamic. And then when the iPhone
came out, I was one of the early app
developers on the iPhone and Android
devices. And one of the first apps I
built was the Wikileaks mobile app,
right? It basically allowed people to
view the documents, search through the
material. Um, and um, I I helped with
the fundraising for it, unfortunately,
until the government froze the bank
accounts, blocked the PayPal, Visa,
Mastercard donation channels, which
which got us as an organization to start
using Bitcoin. This was um 9 cents a
bitcoin. You know, very lucky and
fortunate to uh be introduced to that
world. Then um built a video
conferencing app similar to Zoom or
Skype, decentralized video calling, grew
it to a few million users and then I
sold in 2013. Uh worked at the third
biggest uh venture capital fund in
Europe. We were seed investors in uh
Spotify, Wellington Partners. Mhm. Also
worked for the Founders Forum. It's one
of the most exclusive tech communities
in the world. to be invited you need to
have started a half billion dollar
company rebuilt their systems and now
I'm um investing in uh investing from my
family office where we are investing in
businesses which use tokens instead of
equity and show what the future of the
economy looks like and then we also have
a blockchain called the unit network
which reimagines how the economic system
works and we're really excited to see
how it can transform the world. Let's
talk about unit network. Um obviously
that that's why we're chatting to you
today. Um, I think that there's quite a
few different uh very decent blockchain
protocols that allow you to do RWA
tokenization and those sort of things.
Why do we need another blockchain
network and what is unit network do that
others don't? It's a great question. I
mean, a lot of times when people say
tokenization or RWA, it's been so often
talked about that people just switch off
and they're like, do we really need
another RW tokenization? This wasn't the
case two or three years ago, but now,
you know, people think there's money to
be made in this um trend or this
narrative. So a lot of people just
spinning out companies. I think where
unit network really stands out is most
people think about tokenization RWA as
traditional finance with a blockchain
sort of front or marketing um rapper,
right? They look at treasury bills, they
look at real estate, they look at
publicly traded companies like Apple or
Google or Tesla, right? Or they look at
maybe money markets funds or private
equity. where unit is interested in is
the hundreds of millions of companies
that exist and the billions of people in
the world. You know, I would love to be
able to buy a piece of you as a person
and when you become even more
successful, you know, get a tiny piece
of your economic success or the idea
that everyone listening can buy a piece
of Michael and if you know um I if if
people can be much more collaborative
and supportive of one another, I think
this is going to redefine how the role
of money exists in society. You know, if
you look at the smartphone, how it
revolutionized access to communication.
You look at the um the internet, how it
made information readily accessible. You
know, no matter how much money you have,
where in the world you lived, you had
access to abundant information, right?
Wikipedia, you know, YouTube videos, um
the smartphone did that for
communication. I'm convinced that the
unit network can take crypto from the
three three trillion it is as an asset
class to hundreds of trillions and
really take this technology of
blockchain mainstream and really solve
problems for people, make fundraising a
lot easier and turn everyone into a
micro investor. Okay. When it when it
comes to all the other chains that are
out there, I mean, how do you view the
competition and how are you going to
approach like gaining market share?
Because I think that's the most
difficult problem now is everyone's kind
of fighting for the same piece of the
pie. the protocols do different things
and there's there's there will be a lot
of advantages for tokenizing securities
on Salana versus Ethereum versus SU or
Aptos like why would I why would I do it
on unit network spot on so I think you
know we're sort of competing and
operating in a completely different
league I think a lot of people are
talking about tokenization and saying
hey you know if you have a $50 million
asset or $100 million fund or you know a
company in you know on the stock
exchange wherever you can use our
blockchain to access that financial
asset right we think that's interesting
but we think the more interesting
opportunity is, you know, your local
coffee shop that might, you know, grow
to become the next Starbucks, right? Or
let's say your friend who's an aspiring
actor, right? If they become the next
Tom Cruz or, you know, Scarlett Johnson,
you know, the idea that, you know, you
can follow them and, you know, be
involved in their journey, right? That
wasn't the case 10 years ago, but now it
is. And the next evolution of that is
people to own effectively digital
shares, which we think are tokens. I
don't think any of the blockchains I've
come across provide a super easy way for
a non-coder or non-technologist or
non-blockchain person to create coins
and easily fund raise with it and have
the community partake in their upside.
You know, the employees, the customers,
the next Uber or Airbnb, you know, will
be built on chain and will be
cooperatively and community owned. Um,
I've got a question coming through from
the live stream and if you are watching,
please do keep them coming through. Um,
you know, we're hearing about something
new and innovative and I think it's
great to take some questions. So this
one is Wi-Fi Frodo. That's a great
username. Why should I trust unit to
manage tokenized value when a lot of web
3 projects struggle to survive a bare
market? Great question. So I mean we've
been I I've personally been passionate
about securitization and tokenization
for 10 years, right? Um we've been
relatively quiet and low-key for the
past 2, three, four, five years because
of regulatory um reasons. You know, I
had a meeting with the new crypto star
David Saxs. He basically told me um you
know Michael the current rules and
regulations likely won't change but
there is potential for this new
technology something like unit network
to supersede the old system to make it
less relevant kind of like you know how
can I trust when I walk into an Uber I'm
not going to be kidnapped or you know
murdered or robbed or if I stay in an
Airbnb you know is am I going to be um
you know under any risk or why should I
put my apartment which might be worth
millions of dollars rent it out for $200
a night. I think there is that hurdle
you know if someone's you know operating
a business which makes lots and lots of
money or even a small bit of money why
should they incorporate this idea of
tokenization it's the same as social
media when it came out you know people
doubted the potential of using social
media for marketing and then you know
now it's common it's like you know if a
business does have a Tik Tok account
Instagram account social media account
it's just not um yeah it doesn't make
sense not to have one so we're convinced
every company in the world will have
their own coin every person in the world
will have their own coin and be
investable. Their friends and family
will own a piece of them. Um, and I
think the trust is we should move to a
society where you do not have to trust.
You can verify. So, the cool thing about
unit network is unlike most
decentralized apps, it's entirely on
chain. So, you know, many apps maybe
only the settlement is on chain. What
we've built is a blockchain where every
single piece of the um the software is
um on the runtime, not even using smart
contracts, it's on the actual blockchain
layer. It's using the same framework as
Bit Tensor or Tao called Substrate. Um
I'm really proud of of the technical uh
innovation development that we've
achieved and I think it's just a matter
of time. Our goal is to get into the top
10 or 15 crypto assets in the world. Um
and then you know maybe even someday
overtake uh Bitcoin and Ethereum. Here
we go. Um, I've got another good one
here. You're promoting tokenization for
everything, but who profits, the users
or the early insiders? Great question.
So, I think we've created mechanisms to
provide much more disclosure. So, if
there is um fraud or insider trading or
you know um malicious activity, it will
be much more open. Right now, you know,
if you see addresses move or you see
token balances, you you kind of have no
clue about the analytics behind them.
So, we've basically built 25 apps. One
is a um decentralized Uber, one is a
decentralized Spotify, a poker app, you
know, a ticketing app. Um, one is called
u unit screener. So, this is going to be
like a Bloomberg terminal for the token
economy. So, you'll be able to have much
more insight as to is this project
legitimately generating profit, putting
money into the tokens treasury, which
basically backs up the underlying um
value for that token, or is it just, you
know, a bunch of people looking to pump
and dump or um there's no actual
business behind it. So, I really think
that's the innovation that we have. You
you guys recently raised $80 million.
Maybe you can chat about some of the
venture funds or or the people that were
invested in the raise uh to help you
scale the the chain. Um and
additionally, how hard is it to convince
people to invest in a new layer 1 in

got a like they were really build as the
next genes.
How do you how do you convince people to
give you money? Definitely. So, we've
got some really um strong backers,
right? Outlier Fund, Blockchain Founders
Fund, Moon Pursuit Capital, um X
Ventures, who's who's organizing this,
and countless others. People who've been
in the space um you know, for 10, 12,
13, 14 years. Um I I think where we
stand out is, you know, we're not just
building a piece of technology and
looking to solve a problem. You know, I
I'm I've built um tech products and
companies before and realized, wow,
wouldn't it be cool that, you know, when
I sold my app, I didn't have any
external investors. Wouldn't it have

could have parttook in the upside, all

know hundreds and thousands of
entrepreneurs but it's very easy very

just invest that capital but be able to

successful right so I think you know
unit network is a layer one blockchain
we believe that we can be in the leading
you know top five top 10 blockchains in
the world but we we kind of take the
approach of you know we want to create a

cooperative we want to make the idea of
money ownership and equity radically
different now how do we solve that we
started off building with Ethereum you
know, with Solidity, we we then tried to
work with Polygon. We tried a bunch of
other layer 1 and layer two chains and
then we opted for building our own chain
and then we realized that Substrate was
the best framework to do so. Mhm. Yeah.
And I mean you you you touched on like
Bit Tensor being, you know, also working
on on Substrate. You take some
inspiration from the way that they built
their infrastructure. Uh good question.
So I I I actually to some extent you
know the subnetss but I was an early
restaurant polka dot in 2017 and um and
you know I think what Gavin Wood created
with Ethereum and basically took his

building substrate as a framework um was
was really powerful. Um
um so I I'm have huge respect for Bit
Tensor. I was an investor in TA since I
think 2022. Um I I think what's really
cool there is I believe AI and robots

as if there needs to be tools by which

tens of trillions and hundreds of

could ensure that people are going to
live a much better life. You know it
will be basically like now we have
two-day weekends. I think you know it
will extend to a 4-day weekend to a
5-day weekend to a 7-day weekend. So
what you do in your passion you know
will be what you do for work and life.
How um yeah, I've I've got a couple of
my director is pointing at me to ask
some questions here. So I' I've got them
coming from the from the live stream as
well. I know we've only got a couple

uh one of them here is if unit was to

57 people at the moment. we expect to

intend on decentralizing where similar
to bitcoin the protocol doesn't change
if someone wants to extend it or change

base protocol is so simple and possible
enough where you know none of it is is
centralized you know one one question is
hey you know if I deposit bitcoin onto

ton or sooie where does that go and
initially we followed uh centralized

bit And we thought okay you know this is

possible. Okay. Yeah. Um, this is quite

chat. Doesn't tokenizing people in their
work turn humans into commodities? What

about the regulatory frameworks here.
And it's not just the regulatory

a machine is a moral machine oxymoron?
So, is AI um can you say a robot can

So my perspective and thesis to
tokenizing people is that you know you

where people are invested in supporting

you know you don't have to um think am I

when the unit network um grows to
hundreds of millions of businesses and

money will still exist right as a as a

And you know a lot of people have a lot
of trauma or bottleneck around the

this idea of cooperative ownership is

someone says hey you know um I'm going

lunch? Absolutely. So you know one

password pin to um to login or to create

it's an easy way for anyone on around
the world if they lose their 12-word

at least use the email password pin. So,
they still have self-custody, but the
experience is just seamless. I think,
you know, if you look at how the

you know, Facebook only came out in 2004
and it transformed social networking.
Um, Google came out in 200 207, but 2001
was when it really took took off. you
know, unit you could say is is launching

you know, the next 6 months are going to
be incredible, not just for the unit
ecosystem, but for the token economy.
And I I'm optimistic that the same way,
you know, ICOs, NFTTS, now memecoins

idea that customers and employees are
stakeholders is what's going to make the

"Wow, I would love to partake in the

even more successful business, they're
not just happy because of of, you know,
that person or business's success, but

Sanain um about their Bitcoin holdings

you.

Good afternoon. Welcome back to the proof of talk live stream. My name is Gareth Jenson. I'm the managing, uh, I'm the head of multimedia. I used to be the managing editor at Cointelegraph. We've been live streaming all day. So, as you can hear, my brain is fried, but I'm very excited to have this conversation. Um, if you are joining us, uh, on the X, uh, live stream or the YouTube live stream, please do go ahead and drop your comments or questions. We are talking to Michael Healy, who is the co-founder of Unit Network. Um, before we get into any of that, Michael, give me the TLDDR of your history because, uh, you told me some very interesting stuff off air. You're involved in Wikileaks all the way back in the day. Give us the summary in 30 seconds to 1 minute. Most definitely. So, I'm half Singaporean, half British. Um, been building applications since the mid-2000s. So, web 2 effectively when the internet post.com bubble became a bit more dynamic. And then when the iPhone came out, I was one of the early app developers on the iPhone and Android devices. And one of the first apps I built was the Wikileaks Mobile app, right? It basically allowed people to view the documents, search through the material. Um, and um, I I helped with the fundraising for it, unfortunately, until the government froze the bank accounts, blocked the PayPal, Visa, Mastercard donation channels, which which got us as an organization to start using Bitcoin. This was um, 9 cents a Bitcoin. You know, very lucky and fortunate to uh, be introduced to that world. Then um, built a video conferencing app similar to Zoom or Skype, decentralized video calling, grew it to a few million users and then I sold in 2013. Uh, worked at the third biggest, uh, venture capital fund in Europe. We were seed investors in uh, Spotify, Wellington Partners. Mhm. Also worked for the Founders Forum. It's one of the most exclusive tech communities in the world. To be invited, you need to have started a half-billion-dollar company, rebuilt their systems, and now I'm um, investing in, uh, investing from my family office where we are investing in businesses which use tokens instead of equity and show what the future of the economy looks like, and then we also have a blockchain called the Unit Network, which reimagines how the economic system works, and we're really excited to see how it can transform the world. Let's talk about Unit Network. Um, obviously, that's why we're chatting to you today. Um, I think that there's quite a few different, uh, very decent blockchain protocols that allow you to do RWA tokenization and those sort of things. Why do we need another blockchain network, and what does Unit Network do that others don't? It's a great question. I mean, a lot of times when people say tokenization or RWA, it's been so often talked about that people just switch off and they're like, do we really need another RW tokenization? This wasn't the case two or three years ago, but now, you know, people think there's money to be made in this um, trend or this narrative. So, a lot of people just spinning out companies. I think where Unit Network really stands out is most people think about tokenization RWA as traditional finance with a blockchain sort of front or marketing um, rapper, right? They look at treasury bills, they look at real estate, they look at publicly traded companies like Apple or Google or Tesla, right? Or they look at maybe money markets funds or private equity. Where Unit is interested in is the hundreds of millions of companies that exist and the billions of people in the world. You know, if you look at the smartphone, how it revolutionized access to communication. You look at the um, the internet, how it made information readily accessible. You know, no matter how much money you have, where in the world you lived, you had access to abundant information, right? Wikipedia, you know, YouTube videos, um, the smartphone did that for communication. I'm convinced that the Unit Network can take crypto from the three, three trillion it is as an asset class to hundreds of trillions and really take this technology of blockchain mainstream and really solve problems for people, make fundraising a lot easier, and turn everyone into a micro investor. Okay. When it comes to all the other chains that are out there, I mean, how do you view the competition, and how are you going to approach like gaining market share? Because I think that's the most difficult problem now is everyone's kind of fighting for the same piece of the pie. The protocols do different things, and there's there's there will be a lot of advantages for tokenizing securities on Solana versus Ethereum versus SU or Aptos, like why would I, why would I do it on Unit Network? Spot on. So, I think, you know, we're sort of competing and operating in a completely different league. I think a lot of people are talking about tokenization and saying, hey, you know, if you have a $50 million asset or $100 million fund or, you know, a company in, you know, on the stock exchange, wherever, you can use our blockchain to access that financial asset, right? We think that's interesting, but we think the more interesting opportunity is, you know, your local coffee shop that might, you know, grow to become the next Starbucks, right? Or let's say your friend who's an aspiring actor, right? If they become the next Tom Cruise or, you know, Scarlett Johansson, you know, the idea that, you know, you can follow them and, you know, be involved in their journey, right? That wasn't the case 10 years ago, but now it is. And the next evolution of that is people to own effectively digital shares, which we think are tokens. I don't think any of the blockchains I've come across provide a super easy way for a non-coder or non-technologist or non-blockchain person to create coins and easily fundraise with it and have the community partake in their upside.
